conclusion: Identify the forces acting on the ball: electric force and gravitational force.
The electric force acts in the direction of the electric field, which is horizontal. The gravitational force acts downward.
Determine the components of the forces: electric force is qE, gravitational force is mg.
Resolve the forces into components along the path: electric force component is qE cos θ, gravitational force component is mg sin θ.
Determine the net force along the path: F_net = qE cos θ - mg sin θ.
Calculate the work done by the electric force: W_E = qE cos θ * (h/sin θ) = (qEh cos θ)/sin θ.
Determine the change in electric potential energy: ΔU_E = -W_E = -(qEh cos θ)/sin θ.
Relate the vertical displacement to the initial velocity: h = (v_0^2 sin^2 θ)/(2g).
Substitute the expression for h into the change in electric potential energy: ΔU_E = -(qE v_0^2 sin θ cos θ)/(2g).
The difference in electric potential energy of the small ball when it reaches the highest point compared to its electric potential energy at point O is: - (qE v_0^2 sin θ cos θ)/(2g).
